instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00163: What is 820-00163? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V35_S3: What is PP1V35_S3? PP1V35_S3 is a 1.35v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime
threads.message:
ok been working on this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> for a couple days now. It has orange and green lights on charger. fans spin but no chime and no display. Have checked with working display just in case it didn't chime or something in this model. 

History is i I replaced the display 12months ago. It has now come back dead and customer says 'just happened'... there is not any evidence of liquid damage anywhere whatsoever. 

So I thought vcore but after measuring all the following I'm completely stuck now. 

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> 1.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3</SIGNAL> 1.3v
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3RS0</SIGNAL> 1.4v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>SMC_CPUPKG_VSENSE</SIGNAL> 1.9v
*****<SIGNAL>PM_1V5_PGD_L</SIGNAL> 0v ****** not sure if reading this correctly <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.4v
<SIGNAL>DELAY_1V5S0_PGD</SIGNAL> 3.4 **** shouldn't this be 1.5v here at <RESISTOR>R8137</RESISTOR>
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_S3RS0_CPU_DDR</SIGNAL> 1.4v

i don't know where to go from here. Would really appreciate some guidance please. 

Thanks a lot. I'm guessing I'm looking for a reason why the CPU isn't turning on but I can't find one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime
threads.message: USB mouse lighting up? Why was the LCD replaced?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime
threads.message:
Yes a mouse lights up, always wondered what that suggests as I've seen you ask that a few times before. 
Lcd was smashed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00163</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no chime
threads.message:
USB mouse indicates USB initializes. It does depends on the mouse though. Try if a PRAM reset works from an external keyboard and see if caps lock key works.

I do suspect that this board will have failed due to the drop a year ago. Ripped trace under some BGA is a very real possibility.
